column4: It is a realtek RTL-8139/8139C/8139C+ (rev10). I also tried the dhclient again to see exactly what it said as it tried to get an IP, and it said DHCPDISCOVER on eth0 to 255.255.255.255 port 67, interval 7. Does this mean it doesn't know the IP of the DHCP server?
I tried that yesterday and if I do lsmod, 8139cp is already there.
it doesn't need to know the ip of the dhcp server - it broadcasts, and any dhcp server on the network can respond
then try sudo modprobe -r 8139cp (to unload it) and sudo modprobe 8139too (to try an alternate driver)
I will try that and then boot back to XP with my results (or hopefully not have to reboot, and be able to let you know via ubuntu if it works)
after doing both of those, type 'dmesg' and have a look at the output
I lsmod and actulaly have both 8139cp and 8139too loaded at startup. Could that be the problem? It is whatever ubuntu installer set up for me automatically.
the first driver loaded that supports your device is the one that will be used for it.  so, unload (modprobe -r) both of them and try one at a time
I will do that now. Thanks.

When I modprobe -r 8139too, eth0 as an interface completely vanishes (ifconfig eth0 up says no such device). Removing 8139cp and loading 8139too brings eth0 back, but the same problems persist. A static IP cannot ping my gateway, and dhclient gives me the same errors.
did you happen to look at the output of dmesg after you loaded that driver? (I asked you to but you may have already left)
Nope, I'd already left. I'll check dmesg now. Be right back.
What message did you want? When I unload 8139cp ther ei snothing

8139too Fast Ethernet driver 0.9.27; ACPI: ... ->GSI 18 (level, low)->IRQ 193; RealTek8139 at 0xblahblah 00:e0:blah IRC 193; eth0 Identified 8139 chip type `RTL-8139C'; link up, 100Mbps, full-duplex, lpa 0x45e1, and then a few minutes later I get Tx descriptor 0 is 0002000 (queue head); descriptor 1 2 and 3 are the same; then eth0: link up, 100Mbps full-duplex, lpa 0x45E1
